Problem:
Examine a function \\( u(x, t) \\) which solves the partial differential equation (PDE) \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = L u \\) with an initial condition \\( u(x, 0) = u_0(x) \\), where L represents a linear differential operator. We consider the effects of applying the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F} \\) to the initial condition.

Does transforming the initial condition \\( u_0(x) \\) with the Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(u_0(x)) \\) and then evolving according to the PDE change the solution \\( u(x, t) \\) at time t compared to evolving \\( u_0(x) \\) directly?
Explanation: Applying the Fourier transform to the initial condition changes the representation of \\( u_0 \\) into frequency space, thereby modifying how the differential operator L acts on it through its differential properties. This can lead to a different solution \\( u(x, t) \\) compared to the direct evolution of the untransformed initial condition.
